1.text: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honour beseemeth not a fool.

2.text: As the sparrow for flitting about, as the swallow for flying, so a curse undeserved shall not come.

3.text: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the back of fools.

4.text: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him.

5.text: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own eyes.

6.text: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off [his own] feet, [and] drinketh damage.

7.text: The legs of the lame hang loose; so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

8.text: As a bag of gems in a stoneheap, so is he that giveth honour to a fool.

9.text: [As] a thorn goeth up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

10.text: A master roughly worketh every one: he both hireth the fool and hireth passers-by.

11.text: As a dog turneth back to its vomit, [so] a fool repeateth his folly.

12.text: Hast thou seen a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope of a fool than of him.

13.text: The sluggard saith, There is a fierce lion in the way; a lion is in the midst of the streets!

14.text: [As] the door turneth upon its hinges, so the sluggard upon his bed.

15.text: The sluggard burieth his hand in the dish: it wearieth him to bring it again to his mouth.

16.text: A sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than seven [men] that answer discreetly.

17.text: He that passing by vexeth himself with strife belonging not to him, is [like] one that taketh a dog by the ears.

18.text: As a madman who casteth firebrands, arrows, and death,

19.text: so is a man that deceiveth his neighbour, and saith, Am I not in sport?

20.text: Where no wood is, the fire goeth out; and where there is no talebearer, the contention ceaseth.

21.text: [As] coals for hot coals, and wood for fire, so is a contentious man to inflame strife.

22.text: The words of a talebearer are as dainty morsels, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.

23.text: Ardent lips, and a wicked heart, are [as] an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross.

24.text: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, but he layeth up deceit within him:

25.text: when his voice is gracious, believe him not, for there are seven abominations in his heart.

26.text: Though [his] hatred is covered by dissimulation, his wickedness shall be made manifest in the congregation.

27.text: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein; and he that rolleth a stone, it shall return upon him.

28.text: A lying tongue hateth those that are injured by it, and a flattering mouth worketh ruin.
